title: How to Make a Bright Outdoor Candle from Old Wax

steps.headline: Gather your supplies, listed in the "Things You'll Need" section below.
Cut an 8-inch length of steel wire.
steps.description: Be careful when cutting the wire. It can fly up into your face. Wear eye protection.

steps.headline: Measure 3.5 inches (8.9 cm) in from each end (leaving a one-inch segment in the center).
Bend the 3.5 inch (8.9 cm) segments at a 90 degree angle.
Measure 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the 90 degree bends.
Bend the wire around to the inside into a U shape.
Measure about a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) along the remaining ends.
Bend the remaining ends up at a 90-degree angle to form two "prongs".
Trim the vertical prongs to about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm).
Cut two pieces of cardboard 1 inch (2.5 cm) by 2 inches (5.1 cm) by ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) thick.
Insert the prongs in the cardboard so that they hold the cardboard strips vertically.
Cut a piece of aluminum foil twice as wide and 3 times as long as the tray.
Fold the foil over to form a 2-ply sheet.
Carefully push the foil into the tray to form a liner.
steps.description: Do not let the foil rip, as molten wax may escape.

steps.headline: Put the wick assembly in the tray towards one end.
steps.description: Trim the wicks to just above the height of the tray rim.

steps.headline: Break the old wax into small pieces and fill in around the wick assembly.
steps.description: If you are getting the wax from old jar candles, see How to Get Wax out of a Jar Candle for some useful tips.

steps.headline: Fill the tray with enough wax pieces to almost cover the wicks.
steps.description: If you'd like the wax to be scented, see How to Make a Scented Candle in a Glass.

steps.headline: Light one wick and let the wax melt around it.
steps.description: Move the wax pieces around and/or add more wax to keep the wax level high.

steps.headline: Light the other wick and continue to add/adjust the wax.
steps.description: You want no more than a ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) of wicks exposed. Once your candle will burn steadily with minimal soot and strong flames on both wicks, you may enjoy your fire or blow it out. It is primed and will require minimal tending the next time it is lit. Make sure you follow the guidelines in How to Safely Burn Candles.

steps.headline: Place wax fragments in a sturdy glass jar or a metal can.
steps.description: Use the tray to measure how much wax you'll need.

steps.headline: Bring water to a boil and pour it into a bowl.
Put the jar (or can) with the wax in the hot water until the wax melts.
Pour the molten wax into the tray.
steps.description: Do not fill more than 3/4 full. If you happen to spill the wax, you'll find some ways to remove it in How to Remove Candle Wax.

steps.headline: Before the wax solidifies, dip the wick assembly in the wax to coat the cardboard.
Position the wick assembly towards one end of the tray.
After the wax solidifies, trim the wicks to ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm).
Light one or both wicks, and enjoy.

text: Steps Gather your supplies, listed in the "Things You'll Need" section below.  Cut an 8-inch length of steel wire. Be careful when cutting the wire. It can fly up into your face. Wear eye protection. Measure 3.5 inches (8.9 cm) in from each end (leaving a one-inch segment in the center).  Bend the 3.5 inch (8.9 cm) segments at a 90 degree angle.  Measure 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the 90 degree bends.  Bend the wire around to the inside into a U shape.  Measure about a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) along the remaining ends.  Bend the remaining ends up at a 90-degree angle to form two "prongs".  Trim the vertical prongs to about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm).  Cut two pieces of cardboard 1 inch (2.5 cm) by 2 inches (5.1 cm) by ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) thick.  Insert the prongs in the cardboard so that they hold the cardboard strips vertically.  Cut a piece of aluminum foil twice as wide and 3 times as long as the tray.  Fold the foil over to form a 2-ply sheet.  Carefully push the foil into the tray to form a liner. Do not let the foil rip, as molten wax may escape. Fueling Method 1 (Wax Pieces) Put the wick assembly in the tray towards one end. Trim the wicks to just above the height of the tray rim. Break the old wax into small pieces and fill in around the wick assembly. If you are getting the wax from old jar candles, see How to Get Wax out of a Jar Candle for some useful tips. Fill the tray with enough wax pieces to almost cover the wicks. If you'd like the wax to be scented, see How to Make a Scented Candle in a Glass. Light one wick and let the wax melt around it. Move the wax pieces around and/or add more wax to keep the wax level high. Light the other wick and continue to add/adjust the wax. You want no more than a ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) of wicks exposed. Once your candle will burn steadily with minimal soot and strong flames on both wicks, you may enjoy your fire or blow it out. It is primed and will require minimal tending the next time it is lit. Make sure you follow the guidelines in How to Safely Burn Candles. Fueling Method 2 (Molten Wax) Place wax fragments in a sturdy glass jar or a metal can. Use the tray to measure how much wax you'll need. Bring water to a boil and pour it into a bowl.  Put the jar (or can) with the wax in the hot water until the wax melts.  Pour the molten wax into the tray. Do not fill more than 3/4 full. If you happen to spill the wax, you'll find some ways to remove it in How to Remove Candle Wax. Before the wax solidifies, dip the wick assembly in the wax to coat the cardboard.  Position the wick assembly towards one end of the tray.  After the wax solidifies, trim the wicks to ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm).  Light one or both wicks, and enjoy.
